channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Secretive Branch of ISIS Built a Global Network of Killers
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: A jailhouse interview with a German man who joined the Islamic State reveals the workings of a unit whose lieutenants are empowered to plan attacks around the world.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: $400 Million Cash Payment to Iran Fuels Latest Campaign Dispute
item.media:description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, talking to the media during a daily briefing at the White House on Wednesday.
item.description: Donald Trump and other Republicans argued with the White House about what the payment was about: A cash ransom, failed foreign policy or opposition to a nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Pope Francis’ Remarks Disappoint Gay and Transgender Groups
item.media:description: Pope Francis in Krakow, Poland, in July. The pope spoke against what he called ideological colonialism.
item.description: Advocates reacted with dismay after the pope said that schoolchildren are being taught they can choose their gender.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Montreuil Journal: Paris Partygoers, Bored and Short on Cash, Turn Suburbs Into Movable Fête
item.media:description: The Macki Music Festival at the Ourcq Canal outside Paris last week. Young and mostly middle-class Parisians have banded together to establish informal collectives to perform regularly at venues in suburbs.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The capital has seen much of its night life move to the socially and historically estranged suburbs as a new generation establishes an alternative to mainstream dance clubs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: France’s President Says Trump’s ‘Excesses’ Make People ‘Want to Retch’
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France attending a Mass last week in Paris for a priest who was killed by attackers at a church in Normandy.
item.description: President François Hollande said a victory by the Republican nominee in the United States could herald a shift to conservative candidates in other countries.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: In a Victory for Modi, India Overhauls Its Tangled Tax System
item.media:description: A vendor in New Delhi on Tuesday. A protracted battle over a constitutional amendment to introduce a single national goods and services tax came to embody the zero-sum political atmosphere in the city.
item.description: The new measure, a victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will replace a thicket of state and federal levies with a single economic zone.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Boko Haram May Have a New Leader, ISIS Magazine Suggests
item.media:description: A Nigerian soldier amid the ruins of a school in Borno State where Boko Haram kidnapped nearly 300 girls in April 2014.
item.description: An online magazine identified a key Boko Haram member, Abu Musab al-Barnawi, as the “governor” of West Africa, indicating a major promotion.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Abroad in America: Trying to Recognize America in a Wild Campaign
item.description: With less than 100 days until Election Day, a Times foreign correspondent sets out to explain the American presidential race to a global audience.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: South Africans Head to Polls Amid Fierce Challenge to Party of Mandela
item.media:description: Supporters of the African National Congress during a recent campaign event for the mayoral candidate Thoko Didiza at the University of South Africa in Pretoria. Ms. Didiza said she felt confident that the party would retain the Pretoria municipality, officially known as Tshwane.
item.description: In key municipal elections this week, Democratic Alliance candidates aim to loosen the grip of the African National Congress in several cities.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: A Gloomy Egypt Sees Its International Influence Wither Away
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, center-left, with graduates of the Air Force Academy in Cairo in July.
item.description: Long a leader of the Arab world, politically and culturally, Egypt has become inward-looking and politically marginalized in a way not seen for generations.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: The Interpreter: Donald Trump, Perhaps Unwittingly, Exposes Paradox of Nuclear Arms
item.media:description: A deactivated Titan II intercontinental ballistic missile in a silo at the Titan Missile Museum, a preserved military complex near Tucson.
item.description: Since the Cold War, leaders have grappled with the puzzling logic of weapons whose power comes in not being used.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Pentagon Says Deso Dogg, Ex-Rapper and ISIS Recruiter, Survived Airstrike After All
item.media:description: Denis Cuspert, who the Pentagon said was killed in a U.S. airstrike in October, actually survived.
item.description: Defense officials had said that the former German rapper, who was born Denis Cuspert, was killed in an airstrike in October.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Spain’s Political Parties Fail to Agree on Coalition Government
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy of Spain, the acting prime minister, addressed a news conference after meeting with Albert Rivera, the leader of the Ciudadanos party, in Madrid on Wednesday.
item.description: Political deadlock going on seven months could force an unprecedented third round of national elections.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: 33 U.S. Service Members Have Contracted Zika, Pentagon Says
item.description: Military officials said the disease had been found in men and women serving abroad, including a pregnant woman.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Plans Take Shape for François Pinault Museum in Paris
item.media:description: The Bourse de Commerce, center, in Paris.
item.description: The City Council has approved the project, which is to transform an 18th-century bourse into “The Pinault Collection, Bourse de Commerce.”
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Nepal Elects Pushpa Kamal Dahal as New Prime Minister
item.media:description: Pushpa Kamal Dahal, center, won the votes of 363 lawmakers in the 595-member legislature to become prime minister of Nepal on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Dahal, also known as Prachanda, brokered a coalition with a rival party to be prime minister on the condition that he pass the reins to that party in nine months.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: China Sentences Hu Shigen, Democracy Advocate, to 7 Years in Prison
item.media:description: Hu Shigen, in court in Tianjin, China, on Wednesday, has long been an outspoken advocate of religious freedom.
item.description: Mr. Hu, a fierce defender of the right to protest, has already served a 16-year term for helping publicize the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Hong Kong Restricts Election Candidates, Renewing Fears of Lost Rights
item.media:description: Edward Leung of the party Hong Kong Indigenous, leaving an election briefing for Legislative Council candidates in Hong Kong on Tuesday. He said he had been barred from running.
item.description: Election officers have blocked at least five candidates over questions about whether they acknowledge the city as an “unalienable part” of China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: China Reins In Communist Youth League, and Its Alumni’s Prospects
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing last month. The Communist Party has announced a major reorganization of its Youth League, a training ground for many officials who have been marginalized under Mr. Xi.
item.description: The league has served as a cradle for generations of Chinese leaders, who rose through it into the high ranks of the party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Australia Allows Abuse of Refugees to Deter Others, Rights Groups Say
item.media:description: The island nation of Nauru, one of two offshore sites in the Pacific where Australia sends migrants who try to reach its shores by sea.
item.description: Asylum seekers being held on Nauru are denied adequate medical care and exposed to crime, and depression and anxiety are rampant, a report said.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Emirates Airliner With 300 Onboard Crash Lands in Dubai
item.description: All passengers and crew members were reported safe, but traffic was halted at the biggest airport in the Middle East after the plane was engulfed in a fireball.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Bitcoin Plunges After Hacking of Exchange in Hong Kong
item.media:description: A shop in Hong Kong that accepts the digital currency Bitcoin. Bitfinex, a Bitcoin exchange based in the city, said that any outstanding settlements would be made at the price before it reported the hacking.
item.description: Millions of dollars’ worth of the currency was taken from Bitfinex, causing a 20 percent decline in the price, which partially recovered later.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: South Sudan President Fires Ministers Allied to Rival Machar
item.description: South Sudan's President Salva Kiir fired six ministers allied to his long-time rival Riek Machar late on Tuesday, widening a political rift in the world's newest nation.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: North Korea Fires Ballistic Missile Into Waters Off Japan
item.description: It was the closest a North Korean missile had come to Japan since 1998. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called it a “serious threat.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Saudi Inclusion in List of Children’s Rights Violators Resurfaces at U.N.
item.media:description: Houthi supporters during a protest against Saudi-led airstrikes in Sana, Yemen in July. The Saudi-led coalition had been included in a U.N. list in June of armies that kill and maim children.
item.description: Two months after the Saudis persuaded Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to temporarily remove them from the list, the issue remains explosive.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.N. Drafts Agreement on Refugees and Migrants
item.media:description: Refugees and migrants waited for rescue in the Mediterranean Sea off the coast of Libya last month.
item.description: The 22-page “outcome document” contains no concrete commitments and will serve as the basis for the United Nations General Assembly meeting next month.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: U.S. Strikes Help Libyan Forces Against ISIS in Surt
item.media:description: Libyan forces allied with the United Nations-backed interim government firing a shell from a Soviet T-55 tank at Islamic State fighters in Surt, Libya, on Tuesday.
item.description: The new round of airstrikes came as Libyan forces were reported to be making advances in their months-old offensive to oust the Islamic State from Surt.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pope Francis Appoints Panel to Study Women Deacons: Q&A With a Member
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the end of a Mass at the Vatican in April.
item.description: Phyllis Zagano, who was appointed by Pope Francis to study the possibility of ordaining women as deacons, discusses what the group aims to accomplish.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: Bangladesh Offers Bounties for Two Terrorism Suspects
item.media:description: Police officers in July at a roadblock near a cafe that was the site of a bloody siege in Dhaka.
item.description: The men are accused of organizing attacks on foreigners, secular writers and intellectuals.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Franciszek Macharski, 89, Dies; Archbishop Succeeded John Paul II in Krakow
item.media:description: Cardinal Franciszek Macharski in Krakow, Poland, in 2008.
item.description: Cardinal Macharski, a close friend of the pope, was known for his work with the poor.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Obama Defends Trans-Pacific Deal Against Strong Anti-Trade Tide
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore at a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Tuesday.
item.description: Facing opposition from both candidates who want to succeed him, the president vowed to keep pressing for the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, citing its strategic importance.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Turks Can Agree on One Thing: U.S. Was Behind Failed Coup
item.media:description: Mr. Gulen speaking to journalists last month in Saylorsburg, Pa., where he lives.
item.media:credit: Charles Mostoller for The New York Times
item.description: Turks of all stripes believe the United States was involved in the coup attempt, especially because the cleric suspected of leading it lives in Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Body Count Rises as Philippine President Wages War on Drugs
item.media:description: Jennilyn Olayres weeping over the body of her husband, Michael Siaron, who was killed in the Manila metropolitan area last month.
item.description: Since Rodrigo Duterte took office in June, promising a tough stance on drug suspects, more than 400 people have been killed, the news media said.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Czech Man Is Charged With Attempted Terrorism
item.description: The authorities said the 25-year-old mechanic’s arrest was the first known case of a Czech citizen trying to join the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and JAN RICHTER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘There’s Something Going On in Turkey,’ U.S. Colonel Was Told During Coup Attempt
item.media:description: The Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey. The day after the coup attempt last month, the country allowed Americans to begin flying air missions from there again, officials said.
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Erikan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: Senior American military officers at Incirlik Air Base scrambled to figure out what was happening, and reverberations were felt directly at the installation.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A World Vision Donor Sponsored a Boy. The Outcome Was a Mystery to Both.
item.media:description: Young Palestinians at a private swimming pool in Husan. Othman’s aunt Myasar recalled that years ago, strangers had come to Husan with cameras and lined up the children to take photos.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: An Australian asked for help years later to find out what had happened to a Palestinian, and he learned the money had aided the boy’s community — while the family never understood the cards he sent.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Zhai Yanmin, Chinese Rights Activist, Gets Suspended Prison Term
item.media:description: Zhai Yanmin at court Tianjin, China, on Tuesday. He is expected to face strict surveillance and restrictions on his activities.
item.description: Mr. Zhai worked for a Beijing law firm that was at the center of the crackdown on human rights lawyers last year, which ensnared about 250 people.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Turkish Gold Trader Builds a Dream Team of Defense Lawyers
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in 2013. Mr. Zarrab’s legal fees are not known, but if his case goes to trial, they could run in the tens of millions of dollars.
item.description: Reza Zarrab, who is charged with conspiracy to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, has hired more than a dozen lawyers, many of them among the most accomplished in their field.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: What in the World: A Mother’s Love? Of Course. Her Citizenship? Not So Fast.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Glyphstock/shutterstock
item.description: Laws in 27 countries say that only fathers, not mothers, confer their nationality on a child. If Dad is dead or missing, Baby may wind up stateless.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: What in the World: In France, a Recipe Squabble over Marseille Soap
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by neydtstock, nulinukas, nika novak, kai keisuke/shutterstock
item.description: Soapmakers want the government to protect their storied product from foreign imitations — if only they could agree on how to make the genuine article.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: What in the World: Cambodia, Home of ‘The Killing Fields,’ Becomes a Retirement Haven
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photos by Whitelook, Sonya Etchison, Kudla, R Foto/Shutterstock
item.description: Foreigners are finding that their Social Security dollars go far in a country once racked by war and genocide — and the government is glad to have them.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Case for (Finally) Bombing Assad
item.media:description: Damage last month in Aleppo, Syria, from Syrian and Russian warplanes. Secretary of State John Kerry hopes that an understanding with Russia will help restore the ‘‘cessation of hostilities.’’
item.media:credit: Yusuf el Bustani/Anadolu Agency, via Agence France-Presse
item.description: The White House is pursuing a dangerous deal with Russia that will only help Bashar al-Assad hold on to power. It’s time for a drastic change.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS B. ROSS and ANDREW J. TABLER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Editorial: In Libya, a New Front in the War on ISIS
item.description: The new phase of the military campaign against the terrorist group must include a viable long-term plan to help stabilize Libya.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama’s American Idea
item.media:description: On May 26, 1996, Mariana Cook visited Barack and Michelle Obama in Hyde Park as part of a photography project on couples in America.
item.media:credit: Mariana Cook/Courtesy Lee Marks Fine Art
item.description: There is no real America to take back, as Trump insists, because America’s many-hued reality is a ceaseless becoming.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
